title: Already, the new lore is clashing with new lore.
body:
"I - 1 Year. The Battle of Knife Straits. An armada from Bilgewater, led by Miss Fortune and Captain Gangplank – sailing together under an uneasy truce"

This is lore from the Harrowing, since the reboot of lore.

Was this before the Bilgewater even chronologically? Because GP wouldn't have known who MF was.

Was it after? Because if that were the case, I don't see the threat from the Shadow Isles even bringing the two together.

replies.body:
That Harrowing took place before Burning Tides.

The following is how I understand that it went down:  (not a Narrative team Rioter).

Miss Fortune was a well known bounty hunter with ships and crews to her name (that she had hired, welcomed, or tricked into working with her).

Gangplank knew of Miss Fortune and her bounty hunting ways - but Gangplank thought that the bounties on his head were hilarious!  HE was the one who could ensure that his bounties were pride of place in the middle of the bounty board - DARING someone to come at him.  In his mind, no-one would be stupid enough - and so it added to his legend.

When the Harrowing came, every ship and able seafarer was needed.  Every weapon and warm body.  Miss Fortune had weapons, ships, and manpower.  Gangplank had weapons, ships, manpower, and influence.  Of course, Gangplank appearing to need help to fight off the Harrowing would be a sign of weakness, so I like to imagine that he made a great show of 'inviting' people like Miss Fortune and her forces to come along and watch his victory.

Miss Fortune, burning with secret hate for Gangplank, would know how dangerous the Harrowing was, and that it would need _every_ able-bodied soul to fight off.

Because of the terrible danger, Gangplank would have 'generously' invited Miss Fortune to attend.  Miss Fortune would have put on her best fake smile, and accepted the invitation.  

Because if they didn't - the town they both call home would have been full of nothing but wailing spirits within the week.

Just curious, and I'm not saying that you're not welcome here (you totally are <3), but is there a Rioter from narrative team interacting with the board?
Because I don't think I've seen one before, at least on Story & Art.

opposed to the blood covered civil war torn state it is now, HAPPY HARROWING!
You know, thats actually an interesting point. Can Bligewater calm down before the next Harrowing? If not......well.......they may be in for one hell of a ride.
A common enemy has a way to unite the people, especially when that comon enemy is a horde of undead
Eh, I guess. It's eh two little words uneasy truce that really set the mood. It very much changes the feeling of the whole story, but with your theory, they are completely unneeded.

Well even if Gp didn't really see Miss fortune as much of a threat,she is still a bounty hunter and he had still a huge bounty on his head,so it would make sense that Gp would be wary of her,if he had to fight with her at his side.

However after that,she probably didn't have anything to do with him anymore,meaning that once everything was over and she didn't try to do anything to him,he didn't consider her as a threat anymore.

DID he have a huge bounty? Because it seems his hold on BW was pretty solid. I doubt if anyone who wanted him dead was alive, considering the fact the new lore is looking to take it in less of a "champions can take down 1000 normal humans" and more a "they're much better than people but still get shot dead."

He most likely didn't get a bounty in bilgewater(because thats the place that he ruled),but he stole from many people,including swain,whose flagship was stolen by Gangplank.
For other countries he was still a pirate,so of course they would put a bounty on his head.

He knew who "Miss Fortune" was, as the name is an alias. But he never knew that this Miss Fortune was the daughter of the weapon smith he murdered over a decade ago - to him the name was just the one of another captain that lived on his turf. He had never expected her to actually go against him... although that has changed now as MF is now on a slaughter spree, killing everyone that has ever sailed under his flag. 

Once the harrowing is over and GP has gathered some power again Bilgewater will have a civil war that might eradicate the entire town...
But he would have had no reason to have an "uneasy truce" with her, or to even have a truce with her if she was just a captain living under his reign.
She's officially a bounty hunter. And you can bet that there are some people who would pay a LOT for Gangplanks head. That's why they had to make a truce.
He knew about MF's persona. He knew where she was. If he honestly thought that she was a liability, she wouldn't be living in Bilgewater. That excuse doesn't float.

As I said, the name "Miss Fortune" itself is an alias, and Gangplank has never brought it into connection with the woman he has murdered on his raise to power. She was just another captian/bounty hunter living in Bligewater like countless others. Sure it's common knowledge she hates him, but that applies to like 90% of Bilgewater.

You're contradiction yourself.

Either he knew she was a dangerous bounty hunter, and would have gone after her.

Or he didn't. 

If he did, she would be dead.

If he didn't they wouldn't need a truce.

Who's to say he didn't go after her?

He might've already tried to off her at some point and failed. Gangplank's not a dumb man; he wouldn't just send people after he constantly; he'd have made a plan to deal with her. Lull her in to a false sense of security so he can take her out in one go, of course with MF being a secretive lass it didn't help those plans.

And of course what does he gain from killing a single bounty hunter? Not much really. Even if she is reputable he'd only really take offense if MF had gone out of her way to piss him off, but she clearly didn't because her goal was to murder him later. Not to mention the fact that allowing Bounty Hunters to get rid of potential rivals of his actually helps him out in the long run. 

In the end I'd say that MF made her name and fame in such a way that Gangplank knew of her as a bounty hunter but wasn't pissed off by her personally so he didn't make a fuss of it; what's one more bounty hunter in Bilgewater? There's hundreds. If she started barking up his tree he'd shoot her without a second thought, but MF was careful enough to not do that, so when she came to Gangplank (or the other way around; don't know who wanted the truce to begin with) in GPs eyes she was someone who could actually help out the cause; he could dispose of her another time but right then and there she was useful. 

I feel like you're looking at this too simply. Gangplank's not a mindless murdering psychopath and MF's not a crazy murdering psychopath either. They're intelligent people who're smart enough to work around other people to get what they want. And if you're still hung on about the "uneasy truce" deal; it's bounty hunters and pirates working together. Of course the truce is uneasy. Those two things don't exactly work together all that well.
She was dangerous (like many people in Bilgewater are). But not dangerous enough to worry him so much that he would try to kill her. An almost lethal miscalculation...

That Harrowing was before Burning Tides yes.

No he would've known who MF was; a famous (or infamous from his perspective) bounty hunter who commands a lot of respect in Bilgewater. By the time she made a name for herself in Bilgewater Sarah Fortune was already a long forgotten memory to GP, and he likely wasn't a fan of such a reputable bounty hunter.

They had a truce because they're, by rights, enemies by the very nature of their professions. Gangplank rounded up his gangs while MF probably went and rallied the harbour guard and some fellow bounty-hunter crews.

I don't see how this clashes. You'll have to elaborate further.

Based on the new lore, GP had a total grasp on Bilgewater, the only wild card being Sarah Fortune. If he hadn't known that she and MF were the same person, they would have had no need for an "uneasy truce." There would have been no reason to believe they WOULDN'T work together, and the truce would be anything but uneasy. It would be quite mutually beneficial with no downsides.

Heck, if GP thought she was a big enough force in Bilgewater to require a truce, he would have probably arranged an "accident."

MF, according to the new lore, was EXTREMELY secretive and out of the public eye, not wanting to give away her hand and risk tipping off GP.

Personally I just ignore the whole harrowing thingy. It felt like a rushed little timeline without any substance attached.

You're right, it feels quite awkward. Gangplank was basically in control of the entirety of Bilgewater and that sentence makes them seem like equals. 
I'd think Gangplanks whole armada wouldn't get uneasy because one extra ship got added. Already we know there's a monster-hunting fleet that was under Gangplanks control, so even if MF has an impressive ship, it isn't like Gangplank didn't.

Dude, RIOT has long stoped caring about lore. 
They just make up new lore for events, if that clashes with older lore, they wont even notice, they dont even have a lore team anymore, they basicly make some people just write some stuff the can use for new events and the forget about it.
This isn't about old lore clashing with new lore. It's about new lore clashing with new lore.

All lore that is no longer used to sell skins is old lore to RIOT
If The Harrowing gets stronger every year and Bilgewater is in conflict with itself, how are they going to hold off the next Harrowing?

Maybe they won't?

Also, didn't they not have an attack every year?

They do care about the lore, the quality is there, but its not as much as they do for the gameplay aspect of the franchise. While you see patch updates for the game each 2-3 weeks, constant updates, videos about them talking about it, the story update is slow (quality release aside, they are ways to release lore without going full on out like how they do with lore events where they add a bunch of media to make it all visually appealing) lore gets updated each 6-8 months (excluding particular champion releases or full relaunches).  

Thats a big difference in the timescale of things. Which is why if Riot would like to fix the "OMG no lore for months" cry out from fans, their best course of action is to have a steady release of lore articles fleshing out the setting, while they prepare the bigger narrative events. [Building Bilgewater: A Pirate Renovation](http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/special-event/building-bilgewater-pirate-renovation) article is the best example of articles they should be releasing more often. But instead of just talking about a recent event they did, have the articles talk about even the smallest things of the world, like: objects in day to day life, jobs, cultural aspects, flora & fauna.... 

The articles themselves dont have to be something super long, just steady trickle of lore updated in the same interval as the game is.

In short

Old lore > New lore.

I read the Journal of Justice like 8 times D:

I hated the old lore when i first started the game. I thought it was stupid that we weren't the champs. 

It took less than a year for me to change my mind and fall in love.
